results.title: Touch the Sun: Captain Johnno
results.creator_credit: Mario Andreacchio, Jane Ballantyne and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description: Johnno is 10 years of age, deaf and always in strife. He lives in a small fishing town and he has an affinity with the sea that he shares with Tony, an Italian fisherman, whom the townsfolk also ridicule. Johnno’s best friend is his sister, Julie, who is going away to boarding school in the city. When Johnno discovers this news he is devastated and runs away to his secret place - a deserted island. Johnno’s running away causes much havoc in the small community and the experience helps him realise that he must learn to live with his deafness and trust those who love him.

results.title: Ten times empty
results.creator_credit: I Wilson, J Tristram and Juniper Films
results.brief_description: A study of life in a Greek village community on the island of Simi, a barren rocky island lying in the Aegean Sea off the coast of Turkey, with particular emphasis on the surrendering of traditional means of livelihood because of changing economic circumstances. Migration is a central theme of the film, with special reference to Australia. Scenes of the island reveal that despite a lack of factories, farming and jobs, close cultural and community ties bind the 3,000 inhabitants together.

results.title: The Story of Holmesglen Concrete Housing Project
results.creator_credit: Housing Commission of Victoria and Herschells Films
results.brief_description: The Housing Commission of Victoria has a huge project at Holmesglen, a suburb of Melbourne, for the manufacture of prefabricated houses. All components of a modern house or a block of flats are constructed at this factory and transported in bulk to the place of erection. Concrete walls, chimneys, fences, tiles for roofs, plumbing units, wooden door cupboards and other fittings are all shown under construction and are then shown being fitted into place as the house is erected. Credit is given to the research work being carried out by the CSIRO Building Research Division, particularly in regard to a new type of light weight concrete which has been developed there.

results.title: High and wild
results.creator_credit: David Greig and Kestrel Films & Video (Australia)
results.brief_description: High and Wild is the latest video from the Wilderness Society’s ongoing education program. It traces the journey of eight students and their teacher from Melbourne’s Kingswood College on what, for most, was their first wilderness experience. Shot on location in Victoria’s Wonnangatta-Moroka National Park “High and Wild” captures the students’ experience as they explore a variety of issues surrounding wilderness - such as alpine grazing logging, flora/fauna protection, outdoor recreation, Aboriginal and World Heritage values.

results.title: Mary's Story
results.creator_credit: Mary Herbert and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description:
Mary tells of her personal experience living with cerebral palsy. She recounts being told she could never walk, but her parents, determined that she could, helped her achieve this milestone. Mary goes on to speak about the troubles she has faced later in life.
This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Department of Human Services and the Wellington Shire Council.

results.title: Quilts of Understanding
results.creator_credit: Jenene Egan and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description:
In this story, Jenene tells of her life-long passion for all things craft. Recounting one of her proudest moments, she speaks about some patches that she created for a collaborative quilt-making project which was exhibited at her Uniting Church and throughout regional Victoria.
This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Department of Human Services and the Wellington Shire Council.

results.title: Generations of Hands
results.creator_credit: Jennette Moore and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description:
Jennette was born in Ballarat. In this digital story, she talks about her personal experience growing up as a deaf person. She recalls learning how to sign and memories with her little brother and parents. Jennette also tells of her children (one of whom was sadly still-born) and grandchildren.
This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Department of Human Services and the Wellington Shire Council.

results.title: The Next Chapter
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Craig Dawson
results.brief_description:
Craig Dawson shares his personal experience of being diagnosed with Multiple Sclerosis, a disease that his grandmother also suffered from. Craig dedicates this story to her.
This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with the Department of Human Services and the Wellington Shire Council.

results.title: Growing up on Cummera
results.creator_credit: May Andy, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: May is a Yorta Yorta woman who grew up on Cummera Gunja mission. She warmly reflects on her days there, swimming and listening the the elders tell their stories. Moved away from her community, she experienced racism and prejudice but from those experiences learnt to overcome the boundries that others set up for her. She has since committed to a lifetime of learning and teaching and linking children and family back to their communities.

results.title: Growing up in Fitzroy
results.creator_credit: Marlene Scerri, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Marlene (Scerri) Young gives us a picture of what it was like to grow up in Fitzroy in the 1950s. She lovingly tells of the closeness to her extended family, the friends coming to stay over and the strong sense of community, especially the Christmas parades down Smith Street.
